Dunnett’s test: A multiple comparison test intended for comparing each of a number of treatments with a single control
Dunn’s test: A multiple comparison test based on the Bonferroni correction
Duration time: The time that elapses before an epidemic ceases

Gene mapping: The placing of genes onto their positions on chromosomes. It includes both the construction of marker maps and the localization of genes that confer susceptibility to disease
Generalized mixed models (GMM): Generalized linear models that incorporate a random effect vector in the linear predictor. An example is mixed effects logistic regression
Genetic heritability: The proportion of the trait variance that is due to genetic variation in a population
Geographical correlations: The correlations between variables measured as averages over geographical units. See also ecological fallacy

For the next 20 years he worked first as a statistician at the New York State Department of Health and then as Director of the Bureau of Vital Statistics at the Connecticut State Department of Health

Haugh’s test: A test for the independence of two time series which is based on the sum of finitely many squares of residual cross-correlations
Helsinki declaration: A set of principles to guide clinicians on the ethics of clinical trials and other clinical research. See also Nuremberg code
Interruptible designs: Experimental designs that attempt to limit the information lost if an experiment is prematurely ended
IRLS: Abbreviation for iteratively reweighted least squares

Likert was born in Cheyenne, Wyoming and studied civil engineering and sociology at the University of Michigan
Local dependence fuction: An approach to measuring the dependence of two variables when both the degree and direction of the dependence is different in different regions of the plane
Log-F accelerated failure time model: An accelerated failure time model with a generalized F-distribution for survival time
Logistic normal distributions: A class of distributions that can model dependence more flexibly that the Dirichlet distribution
Mathisen’s test: A distribution free test for the Behrens–Fisher problem

McCabe–Tremayne test: A test for the stationarity of particular types of time series

Psychometrics: The study of the measurements of psychological characteristics such as abilities, aptitudes, achievement, personality traits and knowledge
Quality-adjusted survival times: The weighted sum of different time episodes making up a patient’s survival time, with the weights reflecting the quality of life of each period

Rao–Blackwell theorem: A theorem stating that any function of a sufficient statistic is the unique minimum variance unbiased estimator of its expectation

title: Born in Budh, India, Sukhatme graduated in mathematics in 1932 from Fergusson College in Pine. He received a Ph.D. degree from London University in 1936 and D.Sc. in statistics from the same university in 1939. Sukhatme started his career as statistical advisor to the Indian Council of Agricultural Research, and then became Director of the Statistics Division of the Food and Agriculture Organisation in Rome. He played a leading role in developing statistical techniques that were relevant to Indian conditions in the fields of agriculture, animal husbandry and fishery
Super-Duper: A random number generator arising from combining a number of simpler techniques
Sylvan’s estimator: An estimator of the multiple correlation coefficient when some observations of one variable are missing

title: Symmetrical distribution: A probability distribution or frequency distribution that is symmetrical about some central value
Taguchi’s minute accumulating analysis method: A method for the analysis of interval-censored observations
Theil-Sen estimator: An estimator for the slope of a linear regression equation linking two variables which is based on the median of the slopes of all pairs of points
Three-stage sampling: A process that involves sampling the subunits from a two-stage sampling instead of enumerating them completely

title: Transition models: Models used in the analysis of longitudinal data in which the distribution of the observations at each time point is considered conditional on previous outcomes. Unlike marginal models, these models have no representation in terms of cross-sectional data. The models are comparatively straightforward to use in practice and applications with binary data, for which the models represent Markov chains, are widespread. See also ante-dependence model

container-title: Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series C
title: Transmission probability: A term used primarily in investigations of the spread of AIDS for the probability of contracting infection from an HIV-infected partner in one intercourse
Treatment cross-contamination: Any instance in which a patient assigned to receive a particular treatment in a clinical trial is exposed to one of the other treatments during the course of the trial

note: Trimmed mean: See alpha-trimmed mean.

title: Triogram method: A method for function estimation using piecewise linear, bivariate splines based on an adaptively constructed triangulation

Tumorigenic dose 50 (TD50): The daily dose of a chemical of interest that gives 50% of the test animals tumours by some fixed age

container-title: Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B
title: Turnbull estimator: A method for estimating the survival function for a set of survival times when the data contain interval censored observations. See also product limit estimator

container-title: Journal of the American Statistical Association
title: Umbrella ordering: A commonly observed response pattern in a one-factor design with ordered treatment levels, in which the response variable increases with an increase in treatment level up to a point, then decreases with further increase in the treatment level

VARCL: Software for analysing multilevel models. See also HLM and MLwiN
